items.title: What is a domain and hosting service?

content.text: A domain name (e.g. example.com) is like the address of a house. When someone types it into their browser, it leads them to your website.
The hosting (web hosting) is the house itself: the place where your website‚Äôs files (text, images, database) are stored.
Domain and hosting are both required to make your site accessible to everyone. If either one is missing, the site won‚Äôt work.

items.title: What is the difference between WordPress and custom-developed websites?

content.text: WordPress is a ready-made system used by millions. It‚Äôs like a pre-built house that you can rearrange inside: pick a theme and add plugins. It‚Äôs faster and cheaper, but less flexible.
A custom-developed website is built from the ground up specifically for you. It‚Äôs like designing your own villa: you get exactly what you want, but it takes more time and budget.
In short: WordPress is the ‚Äúready-made house‚Äù, while custom development is the ‚Äúself-built home‚Äù.

items.title: Why is the maintenance of WordPress websites necessary?

content.text: WordPress is like a smartphone: it needs regular updates or it becomes outdated and insecure.

items: Updates: new versions of the core, themes and plugins keep the site more secure.
Security: without updates, your site can be hacked easily.
Performance: updates often make the site faster.
Preventing conflicts: outdated plugins frequently clash with each other.

content.text: Maintenance is like servicing a car: skip it for too long and it will eventually break down.

items.title: Why does a custom-developed website cost more than a WordPress site?

content.text: Custom development requires more working hours and expertise, which is why it costs more.

items: Every feature is built from scratch, there is no ready-made template.
Fully tailored to your exact requirements.
More secure and faster because it isn‚Äôt overloaded with unnecessary plugins.
A long-term investment that can be expanded more easily.

content.text: It‚Äôs like the difference between an IKEA cabinet and a custom-built piece of furniture made by a carpenter.

items.title: How much does a website cost in the long term?

content.text: A website isn‚Äôt a one-off expense. There are ongoing costs as well:

items: Domain fee: paid yearly, usually a few to several dozen euros.
Hosting fee: the cost of running the server, generally billed monthly or annually.
Maintenance: updates, bug fixes and backups.
Further development: when you need new features.

content.text: It‚Äôs like owning a car: the purchase price is just the beginning ‚Äî fuel, insurance and servicing also matter.

items.title: What do marketing costs consist of?

content.text: Marketing budgets are made up of several elements, not just the ads themselves.

items: Ad spend: the amount paid directly to platforms like Google, Facebook or others.
Campaign management: the fee for the specialist or agency that runs and optimises the ads.
Content creation: writing copy, designing visuals and producing videos.
Tools: subscriptions for email marketing software, SEO suites and analytics platforms.

content.text: Think of marketing like a machine: you invest not only in advertising but also in the work that keeps it running.

items.title: What is the difference between Google Ads and Facebook advertising?

content.text: Google Ads appear when someone is actively searching for something. If they type "hairdresser Berlin", they see ads straight away.
Facebook ads create interest. They reach people who might not be looking right now, but could be interested.
In short: Google targets the buying moment, while Facebook focuses on generating attention.

items.title: What is SEO and why is it important?

content.text: SEO (search engine optimisation) helps Google value your site more. You rank higher in search results, so more people find you without paying for clicks.
In short, SEO is like a free billboard inside Google.
An insecure website can be hacked easily, which can have serious consequences:

items: Customer data and passwords can be stolen.
Attackers can inject malicious ads or malware.
Google may blocklist your site.

content.text: A secure website is like putting a lock on your shop door: it protects your business and your clients‚Äô trust.

items.title: Why are a Privacy Policy and Terms & Conditions necessary?

content.text: These documents are required by law and they also build trust.

items: Privacy Policy (GDPR): explains how you use visitors‚Äô data.
Terms & Conditions: essential especially for online shops, covering the buying process, guarantees and withdrawal.

content.text: Without them you risk fines, and visitors will hesitate to trust you.
